docs.lead_paragraph: When Americans go to the polls next month they will cast a vote not just for president but for one of two profoundly different visions for the future of the country’s health care system.

headline.seo: Health Care Direction Awaits Verdict of Presidential Race
headline.main: This Election, a Stark Choice in Health Care
headline.print_headline: This Election, A Stark Choice In Health Care

docs.abstract: American voters will chose between two profoundly different visions for the future of the country's health care system when they cast ballots in the presidential election; victory by Pres Obama would mean a full implementation of the Affordable Care Act and a wide expansion of the health safety net, whereas Mitt Romney would likely repeal much of the law and attempt to shrink costs related to Medicaid and Medicare.
docs.snippet: When Americans go to the polls next month they will cast a vote not just for president but for one of two profoundly different visions for the future of the country’s health care system.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By ABBY GOODNOUGH and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Baby boomers are likely to retire later than the people who came before them, but some of the reasons really are positive.

headline.seo: Retirement Is Later for Many Americans
headline.main: Will I Ever Get Off This Treadmill?

docs.snippet: Baby boomers are likely to retire later than the people who came before them, but some of the reasons really are positive.

docs.lead_paragraph: We spend nearly $1 trillion a year for the needy. It isn’t working.

headline.main: The Wrong Way to Help the Poor
headline.print_headline: The Wrong Way to Help the Poor

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Gary E MacDougal, author and former business consultant and executive, underlines need for serious debate over question of how to lift 46 million Americans out of poverty; questions whether federal spending on helping the poor is being used wisely; expresses hope that issue will come up in vice-presidential debate.
docs.snippet: We spend nearly $1 trillion a year for the needy. It isn’t working.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John D. Rockefeller, a Democrat from West Virginia, said he was concerned that personal information about people could be collected and sold to their potential detriment.

headline.seo: Senator Opens Investigation of Data Brokers
headline.main: Senator Opens Investigation of Data Brokers
headline.print_headline: Citing Deep Data Collections, Senator Opens Inquiry of Information Brokers

docs.abstract: Senator John D Rockefeller IV, responding to growing force of the multibillion-dollar data brokerage industry, opens extensive investigation of nine leading information brokers; says he is concerned that personal information about people can be collected and sold to their potential detriment.
docs.snippet: Senator John D. Rockefeller, a Democrat from West Virginia, said he was concerned that personal information about people could be collected and sold to their potential detriment.

docs.abstract: President Obama's supporters should move away from the ledge and come back inside.

docs.snippet: Doug Wheat, a certified financial planner with Family Wealth Management, answered reader questions about financial planning for retirement.

docs.lead_paragraph: Behind every nonpartisan institution, the right sees the malevolent hand of a liberal cabal. Just look at the latest outrageous charge by the far right that an improvement in the jobs report must have been manipulated.
docs.abstract: Editorial condemns the Republican Party for continuing to see Pres Obama as the center of a malevolent liberal conspiracy to upend truth; contends that by attempting to discredit reports by important nonpolitical institutions that are seen as even marginally beneficial to Obama's re-election chances, Republicans are doing long-term damage to citizens' trust in government.
docs.snippet: Behind every nonpartisan institution, the right sees the malevolent hand of a liberal cabal. Just look at the latest outrageous charge by the far right that an improvement in the jobs report must have been manipulated.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the roiling state-by-state war, the campaign against same-sex marriage has been masterminded largely by Frank Schubert, a former corporate public relations executive.

headline.seo: Frank Schubert and the Fight Against Gay Marriage
headline.main: One Man Guides the Fight Against Gay Marriage
headline.print_headline: In the Fight Against Same-Sex Marriage, a Strategist Casts the Issue Anew

docs.abstract: Former corporate public relations executive Frank Schubert, mastermind behind the national conservative push against same-sex marriage, is now focused on opposing ballot initiatives to legalize the practice in Maryland, Minnesota, Washington State and Maine.
docs.snippet: In the roiling state-by-state war, the campaign against same-sex marriage has been masterminded largely by Frank Schubert, a former corporate public relations executive.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The demise of St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village two years ago has led to a struggle for health care supremacy, offering a glimpse at what might be the future of urban medicine.

headline.seo: After Losing St. Vincent’s Hospital, Manhattan Sees Rise in Clinic Care
headline.main: New Style of Health Care Emerges to Fill Hospital’s Void
headline.print_headline: Walk-In Clinics Filling Hospital Void Downtown

docs.abstract: Demise of St Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village in 2010 has led to a struggle for health care supremacy in Lower Manhattan, offering a glimpse at what might be the future of urban medicine; walk-in clinics are filling hospital's void, hoping to show they are more efficient and consumer-friendly than a hospital-based system; some are already forming relationships with hospitals.
docs.snippet: The demise of St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village two years ago has led to a struggle for health care supremacy, offering a glimpse at what might be the future of urban medicine.

keywords.value: New York University Langone Medical Center
keywords.name: organizations
